About Me

01

I'm Packiyathasan Mithila, a passionate and self-driven Computer Science and Software Engineering undergraduate at SLIIT Northern Uni, with hands-on experience in both web and mobile development. Currently interning at CodeVita, I'm strengthening my skills in Laravel, Flutter, and modern web technologies such as PHP, JavaScript,Tailwindcss,MySQL, and Bootstrap. I enjoy building projects that solve real-world problems ranging from a Student Management System and School Staff Management System to an engaging Country Flag Game App. My interests lie in creating user-friendly, efficient, and scalable software solutions, while continuously learning new technologies and collaborating in team environments to turn ideas into impactful digital experiences.

My Projects

02

EduSync – School Management System

EduSync is a full-featured school management platform built with the MERN stack and PostgreSQL, designed to help administrators and teachers efficiently manage academic operations. The system includes modules for classes, labs, faculty members, and departments, each with complete CRUD functionality for easy data management. The platform features automated class scheduling, allowing admins to generate and organize timetables quickly. Teachers can view their schedules, receive notifications and email alerts for newly scheduled or updated classes, and request leaves or class rescheduling when necessary.

Admins have centralized control to approve leave requests, reschedule classes, and maintain a smooth academic workflow. The teacher dashboard promotes engagement and tracks performance through participation and activity insights, ensuring transparency and collaboration across the system.

EduSync is currently in its final testing phase and is set to be deployed at an elementary and high school in Nelliady within the next six months, according to client requirements.

Arish Fresh Corner – Community Business Assignment

Arish’s Fresh Corner was a physical pop-up dessert and drinks bar launched as part of a campus business assignment, designed to test real-world entrepreneurial and management skills. I led the branding, menu design, and overall operations, while coordinating a six-person team responsible for sourcing ingredients, preparation, and customer service during the university food fair.

Our stall featured a range of blended drinks, mocktails, and desserts, crafted to stand out through creative presentation and taste consistency. Throughout the event, we collected and analyzed customer feedback to refine our offerings in real time, improving both product quality and sales appeal.

By applying structured cost tracking and margin analysis, our team successfully achieved a substantial profit compared to our initial expenditure — demonstrating strong teamwork, strategic pricing, and efficient resource management under a short operational timeframe.

Professional Skills Time-Line

03

I partner product thinking with solid engineering so we can design, build, and refine without losing quality.

  • Technical: TypeScript, React, Next.js, Tailwind CSS, Node.js, REST/GraphQL integrations, automated testing pipelines.
  • Experience led: UX research, design systems, accessibility reviews, and rapid prototyping.
  • Soft skills: Mentoring, storytelling for stakeholders, and staying calm under tight deadlines.

I build trust quickly by communicating often, asking smart questions, and rallying everyone around the same outcomes.

  • Facilitate sprint rituals so contributors know priorities and blockers.
  • Translate complex engineering work into decisions non-technical partners can act on.
  • Adapt to new stacks or domains without slowing down delivery.

I aim for psychological safety, clear communication, and a sense of shared purpose.

My compass: choose the ethical path, give credit freely, own mistakes quickly, and stay curious about how we can create more impact together.

Recruiters get a snapshot of measurable wins, leadership moments, and tech stack at a glance.

  • Bullets open with strong verbs and quantify impact (e.g., “Reduced build time 35% by adding turborepo caching”).
  • Clear structure: Summary, Core Skills, Experience, Education, Certifications.
  • Single-page PDF with consistent typography, accessible contrast, and ATS-friendly formatting.

Good

  • Research the mission, product, and latest releases to tailor responses.
  • Use STAR and quantify outcomes (e.g., “Cut load time 28% in two sprints”).
  • Listen, clarify, and structure answers before diving in.
  • Send thoughtful thank-you notes outlining fit and next steps.

Bad

  • Arriving late or giving generic answers with no preparation.
  • Blaming teammates or sharing impact with no data.
  • Monologues without listening or asking clarifying questions.
  • Skipping follow-ups or curiosity about the roadmap and team.

EduSync—a smart school timetable manager built with React, Tailwind, and an API layer that spots conflicts quickly.

  • Automated clash detection, visual timetables, and real-time alerts.
  • Worked with admins to streamline bulk edits and approvals.
  • Achieved a 42% drop in scheduling conflicts during the pilot.

Also built SaaS billing dashboards, multilingual chatbots, and WebGL showroom prototypes.

  • Open sessions with outcomes, timeboxes, and a fast alignment pulse.
  • Summarize decisions, assign owners, due dates, and acceptance criteria.
  • Share concise notes in Slack/Notion with links to PRs, tickets, and next steps.
  • Use visuals and analogies so decisions are fast and durable.

Template for exec/stakeholder updates:

Subject: Sprint 18 – Dashboard rollout status

Hi [Name],

• Done: API quota safeguards; QA sign-off
• In progress: Accessibility pass (ETA Fri)
• Risk: SSO vendor slippage — tracking with IT; no action needed

Thanks,
Mithila

  • Lead with the summary/ask; limit paragraphs to three sentences.
  • Use specific subjects and bold deadlines/owners when relevant.
  • Proof for tone, forwarding, and clarity before hitting send.

I structure proposals so saying “yes” feels natural:

  1. Problem: Who’s impacted, how often, and the cost of delay.
  2. Solution: Phased plan, scope boundaries, dependencies, success metrics.
  3. Investment: Budget, team capacity, tooling, and assumptions.
  4. Impact: ROI model, risks and mitigations, plus the decision request.

I flex between leading and supporting so throughput and learning stay high.

  • Ran engineering guilds covering documentation standards, testing, and DX tooling.
  • Coached juniors via pairing, review checklists, and growth plans.
  • Celebrated milestones and hosted blameless retros with action items.
  • De-escalate by mirroring concerns and confirming shared goals.
  • Give private, behavior-based feedback tied to outcomes.
  • Protect focus time while staying responsive to critical issues.

This keeps momentum high even when timelines compress.
